title: Easter: Jesus's sacrifice doesn't make any sense.

author: Guitargirl696
text:
Let's go over the theology and then the historicity.

God gave humans free will. Humans chose to sin, which in turn broke the bond which we had with God. We became unrighteous, and God cannot allow unrighteousness into Heaven. He could have left us alone, but He didn't. He loves us and wants us to be with Him. So from the beginning, He set His plan in motion to send His Son to die for us, and we can see this all throughout the Old Testament. When Christ came, He was fully man and fully God. When Je was crucified, He took our place on the cross for punishment. Because we are sinful, and because God is just and righteous, God has to punish us. But, Christ took our place on the cross and bore the weight of our punishment upon Himself. While on the cross, the weight of every single sin committed by every single person who will ever live was upon Christ as God poured out His wrath and judgement. But, the purpose of His crucifixion didn't stop there. He rose again to defeat death, so that we can go to Heaven to be with God. Now, all we must do is accept Christ as our Savior, and we can be cleansed in the eyes of God in order to attain salvation and go to Heaven for eternity.

For the historicity, it was far more than a "desert cult making things up". We have secular documentation of Christ in many aspects. Moreover, we have secular writings of the three hours of darkness which occured at the time of the crucifixion which was prophesied in the Bible and was otherwise an impossible occurrence. Greeks and Romans wrote of this, and we even have some evidence of the Chinese documenting the same occurrence. If it was merely a cult making things up, there would not be the secular affirmations which there are.

Hopefully this helps clear things up.

author: bac5665
text:
>Let's go over the theology and then the historicity.
>
>God gave humans free will. Humans chose to sin, which in turn broke the bond which we had with God. We became unrighteous, and God cannot allow unrighteousness into Heaven. He could have left us alone, but He didn't. He loves us and wants us to be with Him.

This is the part that makes no sense at all. God can choose to change any of these facts. He can make humans not have free will. He could give us free will but make us not be capable of sin, the same way we're not capable of flying or telepathy. He could make it so that sin doesn't make us unrighteous, or he could allow unrighteous people into heaven. God made the rules, and he can change the rules, if he doesn't like the outcome.

And that's setting aside that humans did not choose to sin. Adam and Eve didn't know what sin was, didn't know right from wrong. They didn't know that it was wrong to disobey God. Further, God put the serpent in the Garden. If I were in a perfect Garden, build by a perfect God, I too would assume that a talking snake I found there was there because God wanted it there, and that I could trust it.

So this entire set up makes no sense from top to bottom. It reads like a toddler trying to explain to his parents why he broke a lamp: it just fundamentally misunderstands morality at every step.

>So from the beginning, He set His plan in motion to send His Son to die for us, and we can see this all throughout the Old Testament. When Christ came, He was fully man and fully God. When Je was crucified, He took our place on the cross for punishment. Because we are sinful, and because God is just and righteous, God has to punish us. But, Christ took our place on the cross and bore the weight of our punishment upon Himself. While on the cross, the weight of every single sin committed by every single person who will ever live was upon Christ as God poured out His wrath and judgement. But, the purpose of His crucifixion didn't stop there. He rose again to defeat death, so that we can go to Heaven to be with God. Now, all we must do is accept Christ as our Savior, and we can be cleansed in the eyes of God in order to attain salvation and go to Heaven for eternity.

I'm sorry, but this is just childish. Justice requires that the person who did the wrong thing feel remorse, and that they restore the victim to wholeness, so that the wrong never happened. No part of Jesus's sacrifice accomplished those things. You cannot achieve justice by punishing the wrong person. You can't achieve justice at all through punishment alone. And if we had the power to make someone feel remorse without physical punishment, we'd be ethically obligated to do so. Surely God could appear before me this moment and, while respecting my free will, present me with evidence that I have sinned and should feel remorse. I'm a pretty rational guy and I value honestly and personal growth, so I would welcome such an interaction with God.

No, the crucifixion is orthogonal to justice at best, and an evil thing at worst.

And remember, God makes the rules. God can just decree that our sins are redeemed. He has that power. There's no need to torture Jesus. Indeed, it is evil to torture anyone when it isn't necessary.

>For the historicity, it was far more than a "desert cult making things up". We have secular documentation of Christ in many aspects. Moreover, we have secular writings of the three hours of darkness which occured at the time of the crucifixion which was prophesied in the Bible and was otherwise an impossible occurrence. Greeks and Romans wrote of this, and we even have some evidence of the Chinese documenting the same occurrence. If it was merely a cult making things up, there would not be the secular affirmations which there are.
>
>Hopefully this helps clear things up.

This last bit is wrong almost from top to bottom. There is no evidence of darkness, no contemporary writings, and no contemporary secular affirmations of any part of Jesus's life other than a few possible indica of a Rabbi Joshua at approximately the right time, but even that evidence is hardly conclusive. In reality, we know that the history in the Gospels is wrong in several places. So rather than being confirmed, we know that parts of it *didn't* happen.

author: bac5665
text:
But that's not better. Suffering *isn't* worthy of reward. It's evil to encourage suffering by offering to reward it. It's correct to offer sympathy, compassion and healing for those who suffer. But it's correct to do those things because it's good to minimize suffering. Suffering *isn't* good in and of itself.

And we also return to the idea that God makes the rules. A God who demands pain as sacrifice to his glory is an evil God. That's what sadists do. The idea of asking someone I love to suffer so that I can forgive them is repellent to me. It makes me feel soiled to even contemplate asking my wife, say, to suffer in order to make up for some wrong she has done me. And she's an equal. Demanding someone subservient to me to suffer is even worse! It is the job of a leader, a parent, a superior to protect their charges from harm, not to demand payment from them. The symbolic act of the payment of suffering to one's lord is evil. It's literally a recreation of Roman slavery, and later of medieval serfdom, which was a form of slavery.

author: Guitargirl696
text:
We would not have free will if there were limitations. God could not give us free will and still make it so we would never make a wrong choice. That part of your argument simply lacks logic.

God is perfect, just, pure, holy, and righteous. He therefore cannot simply say that sin is okay, because it is absolutely contrary to His nature. Likewise, He cannot simply allow unrighteousness into Heaven. Simply put, He cannot change the rules because we chose to sin.

Adam and Eve had instructions. They were not to eat from the Tree of Knowledge, God had explicitly told them this. When Satan tempted them, he tempted them by saying it wouldn't really be so bad, and asked why would God not want them to eat from it. The serpent was clearly speaking contradictory to God, and they absolutely knew what they were doing because that was the exact thing God explicitly told them not to do.

You don't understand justice, do you? I haven't the foggiest where you got that definition. Someone doesn't have to feel remorse in order for justice to be served, and even after justice has been served, victims are not always restored to wholeness as if the wrong never occurred. This is simply an illogical way to view justice. And surely since you are a rational guy you feel bad when you do something such as lie, or are mean to someone? If so, that is God's way of letting you know you did wrong. If not, that's another problem in itself.

It was absolutely necessary for the atonement to occur through the blood sacrifice of Christ, as blood is the life essence and we see this throughout the Old Testament in animal sacrifices. Notice how we are not required to do that anymore? That is because Christ was the perfect sacrifice for all.

Pertaining to the latter portion, claiming the need for contemporaneous writings is one of the weakest possible arguments one can give to refute documentation for anything. We don't have contemporaneous writings of many ancient figures, such as Pythagoras or even Emperor Nero, yet no one seems to question their existence. That is a null point to make. This also shows you have not done proper research. Greek and Roman historians documented the three hours of darkness from official archives. Some even attempted to explain away what occurred, yet it was quite literally impossible for any natural occurrence to have caused this. Claiming there is no documentation for Christ is just simply unfounded.

author: bac5665
text:
>We would not have free will if there were limitations. God could not give us free will and still make it so we would never make a wrong choice. That part of your argument simply lacks logic.

I have limitations now. I will myself to fly. I will myself to be invisible. I will myself to travel in time. None of it works. But we rightly don't think of those things as lacking free will. If God had limited us from rape just like he limited us from turning invisible, that would be no different and we'd still have free will.

In fact, I cannot rape or kill, now. I feel ill even at the thought of doing such things. I would certainly die before committing those acts if you put a gun to my head and commanded me to perform them. But I still have free will. I can make my choices, withing the things that I can still choose from. It is gibberish to suggest that God could not add things to list of actions we cannot perform without violating our free will.

>God is perfect, just, pure, holy, and righteous. He therefore cannot simply say that sin is okay, because it is absolutely contrary to His nature. Likewise, He cannot simply allow unrighteousness into Heaven. Simply put, He cannot change the rules because we chose to sin.

That's circular logic. God can change what it means to be righteous. Or rather, God could have chosen different things to be righteous in the first place.

>Adam and Eve had instructions. They were not to eat from the Tree of Knowledge, God had explicitly told them this. When Satan tempted them, he tempted them by saying it wouldn't really be so bad, and asked why would God not want them to eat from it. The serpent was clearly speaking contradictory to God, and they absolutely knew what they were doing because that was the exact thing God explicitly told them not to do.

Without knowing good from bad, they cannot know that it's wrong to disobey God. They cannot know that God is good, even, without having already eaten the Fruit.

>You don't understand justice, do you? I haven't the foggiest where you got that definition. Someone doesn't have to feel remorse in order for justice to be served, and even after justice has been served, victims are not always restored to wholeness as if the wrong never occurred. This is simply an illogical way to view justice.

Can you offer another way? You don't actually say what I get wrong or what some better way is. And yes, I agree that justice isn't often achieved. I think justice is probably impossible to achieve. That doesn't mean we shouldn't try or that partial restoration of the victim isn't better than no restoration. One thing you and can agree on is that humans aren't perfect, so we have to do the best we can.

>And surely since you are a rational guy you feel bad when you do something such as lie, or are mean to someone? If so, that is God's way of letting you know you did wrong. If not, that's another problem in itself.

I sincerely hope that you don't need God to tell you that lying is wrong (most of the time). If you think you would murder and rape and steal if not for the Word and love of God, then you are a danger to yourself and others and should immediately go and have yourself committed. I'm serious. That is a horrible, unbearable, insane thing to think and you deserve to get the help you need to learn how to tell right from wrong on your own.

>It was absolutely necessary for the atonement to occur through the blood sacrifice of Christ, as blood is the life essence and we see this throughout the Old Testament in animal sacrifices. Notice how we are not required to do that anymore? That is because Christ was the perfect sacrifice for all.

That doesn't make any sense. Again, God makes the rules. Why did he want animal sacrifices? If anyone asks you to murder an animal for them, and you aren't a literal butcher, call the police on them. They are evil. A good person doesn't ask you to harm animals to glorify them. That's what serial killers do. It's truly alarming to me that you are defending the idea of God needing blood. That's evil. I don't know how else to say it. If you aren't repulsed by the idea of asking for someone's blood as payment for attornment, then you need psychiatric help. A perfect God cannot and does not ask for blood sacrifice, ever. How does blood help God? Why doesn't God care about the pain and suffering of the goat? I care about that pain and suffering, and surely God isn't less moral than I am? No, blood sacrifice is evil and it's only in the Bible because the Bible was written thousands of years ago by humans who didn't know better. We know better now.

>Pertaining to the latter portion, claiming the need for contemporaneous writings is one of the weakest possible arguments one can give to refute documentation for anything. We don't have contemporaneous writings of many ancient figures, such as Pythagoras or even Emperor Nero, yet no one seems to question their existence. That is a null point to make. This also shows you have not done proper research. Greek and Roman historians documented the three hours of darkness from official archives. Some even attempted to explain away what occurred, yet it was quite literally impossible for any natural occurrence to have caused this.

No, you're laughably ignorant about the historical process if you think that. We have contemporaneous evidence for Nero. And we do question whether or not Pythagoras existed. Historians question basically every aspect of Pythagoras's life, and readily admit that we don't know anything about him for sure. We question the existence even of Nero, although not very seriously. The evidence for him is very strong. But of course we still don't know how much we actually know about him: we question all the major events of his life and any historian will tell you that ancient sources were often biased. We know that much of what was written about Nero was political lies, for instance, and some of the main work historians do is to try to read through the lies and determine fact from fiction.

So no, the lack of contemporaneous sources is a big problem. No one claims that Nero did anything that humans don't do today. If you are going to claim that miracles happen, you need extraordinary evidence. Much stronger evidence than we have for the existence of Nero.
